noun.description: The reason for which something is done or created or for which something exists.
examples: the purpose of the meeting is to appoint a trustee
the building is no longer needed for its original purpose

verb.description: Have as one's intention or objective.
examples: God has allowed suffering, even purposed it

phrases: I'm only glad that it was an accident and that he didn't do it on purpose.
Does anybody realise that buses actually drive through the traffic jams or are they coming late on purpose just to annoy you?
Firefighters believe youths who were waiting for them on the estate had started the blazes on purpose.
Trying to be annoying on purpose doesn't strike me as the pinnacle of political broadcasting.
Successful people are not gifted; they just work hard, then succeed on purpose.
origin: Middle English: from Old French porpos, from the verb porposer, variant of proposer (see propose).
